item.title: Interview: Marvel Snap Developer Talks Limited Time High Voltage Mode
item.description:
Card game Marvel Snap is already known for its fast-paced fun, with players battling for control of various locations using iconic heroes and villains from Marvel Comics. Now, in the limited time High Voltage mode, Marvel Snap players get to experience a three-turn game - rather than the usual six - with increased amounts of energy and the ability to draw two cards. With High Voltage, the Marvel Snap development team endeavored to create an experience that felt truly different from a standard game of Snap by changing the core formula in many ways.

Game Rant had the opportunity to speak with design director Ben Hayes about the limited-time mode, which will run from October 16 to October 24. Hayes, who has been playtesting the mode, eagerly discussed his personal deck building strategies and provided helpful tips for Snap players to utilize. He also explained which cards are banned in High Voltage mode, how the Marvel Snap team decided to decrease the turn number from three to six, and much more. This transcript has been edited for clarity and brevity.

Three Cards And Many Locations Cannot Be Used In This Mode

Q: Are there any cards or locations that have been removed for High Voltage mode?

HAYES: The location pool for this mode is significantly smaller than the location pool for other game modes. There are a lot of locations that simply wouldn't do anything - for example, any location that says "On Turn 4 or later..." or "On Turn 5 or later..." Similarly, we don't have Limbo spawning, because we don't want to go from a three-turn game to a seven-turn game.

And there are also some banned cards in the mode. There are three cards you won't be able to play in your deck, which are Magik, Galactus, and Black Widow. Magik [ spawns Limbo] and Galactus [ destroys locations] may be for more obvious reasons. Black Widow is because, with fewer turns and [playing] two cards per turn, we found that skipping a turn of drawing cards was really punishing and really wrecked your whole plan. So we did decide to add it as a third card to the ban list for this event.

Q: What about Agatha Harkness - does her playing cards for you on even turns work differently in High Voltage mode?

HAYES: That's a great question - I don't think I ever put Agatha in a High Voltage deck. But I'm sure people will. I think she'd work fine, given that there are still odd and even turns in the game. I think she'll try to spend as much of your increased energy as she can. She might not always make great plays, but she'll make plays. That sounds great. I hadn't even thought of that.

Why High Voltage Is A Three-Turn Game

Q: How did you decide on three turns specifically in High Voltage mode? Was it always three, or did you experiment with different numbers of turns?

HAYES: We started with four, actually, and the reason we went down to three, and settled on three, was that four still felt more like normal Marvel Snap than we were going for. We really wanted this to feel like a very different experience, something that was really different from any other variation or way you'd played Snap before.

We tried a lot of different things for the energy progression. We tried a lot of fixed numbers of energy as you went for the game. So, like "Three energy on Turn 1, six on Turn 2, nine on Turn 3," or "3-5-8." All kinds of different combinations. And the variable energy, getting 2-5 per turn, is something that the lead designer of this mode, Jules Robins, came up with after we were initially working on it. He took it over to really design it, and develop it, and flesh it out, and get it made. He came up with the energy range, and that did a lot to make deck building more interesting.

Because, if you can imagine, every time we had a fixed number, it really restricted how you wanted to build your deck. Like, 3-6-9, you just play threes and sixes. You just play a three and then a six, or two threes and six and a three. They kind of ran into that problem with every set of numbers, and the experimentation just became way less interesting. But then, when we made it a range, your shackles came off a little bit, and you were like "Well, I'm just going to have a lot of energy. I'm just going to put a lot of cool, expensive stuff in the deck, and just kind of see what happens." It wasn't as much about the precise puzzle of "how do I spend all my fixed amount of energy every turn?" I think that was the biggest thing that we iterated on - the energy number. And I'm really excited that we ended up where we did.

How To Build A High Voltage Deck

Q: What advice would you give to Marvel Snap players regarding building High Voltage decks?

HAYES: What I've done with building High Voltage decks is, I looked at a lot of the very powerful combos in Marvel Snap. In some cases, I tried to figure out where I might be able to put two or even three of these in a deck. So, Wong, Mystique, Absorbing Man are all good examples of cards that really supercharge your output in the game, but have flexibility with a wide variety of cards. Similarly, something like a move card along with Professor X to really lock a location down.

Think "what is a cool combo or strategy that I like to do in Marvel Snap ?" And then realize that, instead of needing to build that out really progressively or sequentially with a curve of energy, or needing to have support cards and finesse the deck building, you can just take the most powerful parts of that strategy and chuck it in the deck. And then you can chuck another thing in the deck, and maybe even a third thing in the deck.

But there doesn't even really have to be [combinations], because, like I mentioned earlier, you can do one thing on Turn 1 and maybe even a different thing on Turn 2. And then, if you have 11 or 12 or 13 energy on Turn 3, you can play almost a completely different strategy, kind of out of nowhere, and it still works pretty well.

So, that's how I build High Voltage decks. I just think: "What do I like doing? What feels really powerful?" and then I cut all the filler pieces out of it, because I don't need them. I don't need to do anything on my turn where i have one energy, or two energy - I can just chuck it all onto the board.

Oh, wait, and you should definitely play Hydra Bob, because Hydra Bob has no downsides in this mode. I don't think Hydra Bob is going to be in every deck, but it's a very good card. It's better than it is in normal Snap.

Playing High Voltage Matches Can Earn Players Valuable Rewards

Q: Players who participate in High Voltage can earn a new card, Agony. Was this card specifically designed for High Voltage mode, or will it work well in normal Marvel Snap games too?

HAYES: I think it's going to fit really well in the normal game. It's nice in High Voltage in the sense that it doesn't take up a slot in its location, effectively, because you play it and then play something else, and it merges into that card. So, in a world where you have a lot more cards and energy, and you might get limited by your slots on a location, it's nice in that way.

So I think it's a totally reasonable card to play in High Voltage after you unlock it, but it's also totally serviceable and strong in a variety of more traditional Marvel Snap decks. It's really good with the Human Torch in a move deck. It's really good with Deadpool - really good with anything that doubles or copies. So, I think it has a lot of applications.

Q: Can you talk briefly about other rewards players can earn via High Voltage?

HAYES: There's Agony, and there's an Iron Man variant that's really awesome. And I think the rest of the rewards are either currency or cosmetics. So it's a similar structure to what you would have seen in Deadpool's Diner [mode]. There's currency rewards, there are cosmetic rewards, there's a new card, and there's a variant. In this case, the variant isn't for the new card, it's for Iron Man. And it's awesome.

[END]

item.title: Destiny 2 Player Makes Their Titan Look Like Game of Thrones' Night King
item.description:
Key Takeaways

  • Destiny 2's community showcases creative Guardian fashion through in-game customization.
  • A player transformed their Titan into the Night King, impressing others with attention to detail.
  • Despite Destiny 2's enduring popularity, it is uncertain if Bungie will develop a new mainline title.

A Destiny 2 player online has made clever use of in-game customization options to transform their Titan into the Night King from Game of Thrones . Over seven years after its launch, Destiny 2 retains a dedicated community that continues to create new things in-game.

In the years since Destiny 2 's release, Guardian fashion has become more of a thing among the community. Bungie has added more customization options over the years, which has only made gamers curious about what's possible in the game. Some players just want to create the coolest-looking Guardian possible, which is fair enough, but some of the most striking creations pay homage to other franchises. There was even one Destiny 2 player who made their Guardian look just like Frodo from Lord of the Rings , showing the variation in characters that gamers are making.

Redditor aBlokeWithaGoat shared their epic Night King creation with the Destiny 2 fashion community online, and it's undeniably awesome. It's based on the Night King's appearance in the iconic Game of Thrones episode "Hardhome," with a picture of the villain included for reference. Everything from the armor to the color of the armor is spot on, and it even has an icy sheen to it. Perhaps most impressive is the small horns on the Destiny 2 helmet, which looks just like the horns featured on the Night King. User aBlokeWithaGoat made all the right choices here, with one player claiming they "ate and left no crumbs."

The Destiny 2 Guardian Looks Just Like Game of Thrones' Night King

Luckily, aBlokeWithaGoat didn't leave gamers in the dark as to how they brought the Night King to life as a Titan in Destiny 2 . They shared all the armor pieces they used for this piece of Guardian fashion, which are as follows: Helm of the Taken King, Augmented Auspice, Iron Pledge Ornament, Veiled Tithes Greaves, and Gensym Knight Mark. Obviously, the colors are important too, and aBlokeWithaGoat also shared the Destiny 2 ornaments needed to bring this in line with the Night King's appearance.

With it being so long since the release of Destiny 2 , it remains to be seen whether Bungie will develop another mainline title in the series. It's somewhat surprising it hasn't happened already, given its enduring popularity. Recently, a Destiny mobile game was revealed by studio NetEase titled Destiny: Rising , but it's unlikely this will placate players looking for a fully-fledged sequel. Layoffs at Bungie a few months back led to much speculation about the series in general, but it's too early to tell what the future holds.

item.title: Remedyâ€™s FBC: Firebreak Could Be the Perfect Blueprint for One Type of Future Release
item.description:
FBC: Firebreak brings the mind-bending world of Control into a multiplayer setting, introducing an intriguing change of pace for developer Remedy Entertainment. The three-player co-op title promises an even deeper dive into Control and its lore, making FBC: Firebreak an exciting new way to explore the game's otherworldly features.

In recent years, Remedy Entertainment has really expanded its capabilities, as both Control and the Alan Wake series have slowly formed into an extended universe. Using a blend of horror and paranormal-focused mystery, Remedy Entertainment's universe has boasted some wonderfully absurd concepts, and FBC: Firebreak seems to take it up yet another notch. Until now, Remedy Entertainment has put most of its energy into single-player narratives, and venturing into multiplayer territory isn't an easy transition. However, if FBC: Firebreak happens to be a successful way to showcase more of Control 's world, then other single-player franchises that are branching out into the multiplayer space will want to take note.

FBC: Firebreak Could Inspire Other Evolving Franchises

Single-Player Narratives Exploring Multiplayer Approaches

When it comes to franchises that have mostly focused on single-player gameplay, Sony comes to mind for many. From God of War to Uncharted , many of the company's biggest franchises have been single-player stories. However, Sony has been aiming to change that. FBC: Firebreak may not be a Sony exclusive, but it could still serve as the blueprint for the company's live-service ambitions. Sony has struggled to get its co-op plans to take off. After the failure of Concord and the cancelation of several multiplayer projects, like The Last of Us Online , the company will need to go back to the drawing board.

As of now, one of Sony's only live-service projects still currently in development is the secretive Horizon multiplayer spin-off. With this project not likely to be released any time soon, Guerrilla Games and Sony could very well be preparing to watch how the launch of FBC: Firebreak goes. This is also a completely new landscape for Remedy Entertainment to explore, so if the studio is able to pull it off with its own IP, then that could give Guerrilla Games the fuel and inspiration it needs in order to properly frame Horizon in a multiplayer setting.

In addition to The Last of Us Online , a Twisted Metal multiplayer project has also been scrapped.

A Unique Look Into Control's Supernatural Lore

The announcement of FBC: Firebreak seems to showcase a well-balanced blend of what makes Remedy Entertainment games so compelling while also succeeding at its co-op mechanics. Of course, this is only in-game footage and has yet to be experienced by players, but the multiplayer gameplay is likely to work if the title stays true to the strange energy of Control . Based on the footage from the reveal trailer, FBC: Firebreak almost looks like a fun blend of Lethal Company and Ghostbusters , which could prove to be a special combination.

FBC: Firebreak will feature a first-person perspective, which is another departure from Remedy Entertainment's usual third-person formula.

The Remedy Entertainment universe is bizarre and absurd, which is what makes Control and Alan Wake such fascinating and beloved series. With FBC: Firebreak , it seems as though this multiplayer spin-off is fully embracing this absurdity by bringing some self-aware humor into the mix. Although the game has yet to reveal a specific release date, FBC: Firebreak is now added to the continuously growing list of major games scheduled for next year. It will be intriguing to see how Remedy Entertainment reworks one of its most popular series as a multiplayer experience. If it proves to be a hit, then other single-player franchises curious about multiplayer spin-offs will potentially have a solid source of inspiration.

item.title: Monster Hunter World: Overpowered Builds That Are A Lot Of Fun
item.description:
Key Takeaways

  • The longevity of Monster Hunter World has led to a strong online community for marathon hunting.
  • Hardcore players create fun and powerful armor sets, enhancing gameplay and hunts.
  • Specialized armor sets like utilizing the Clutch Claw or specific weapon types offer unique gameplay experiences.

It's been nearly four years since the release of Monster Hunter World: Iceborne in 2019 and even longer since the base game debuted on PS4 and Xbox One in 2018. Like with any Monster Hunter game, the title's longevity has allowed for a strong online community to dominate servers, banding together for marathon hunting against terrifying creatures.

In the years after the game's release, there has been plenty of time for hardcore players to create the perfect armor sets to enhance both their in-game strength and their real-world fun. These six builds, which can be obtained by only the very best hunters in Monster Hunter World , are not only the strongest in the game but will allow for some entertaining hunts.

Updated on October 20, 2024, by Blaise Santi : Monster Hunter fans around the world are anxious to get started on the next chapter in the long-running action RPG franchise: Monster Hunter Wilds, set for release in February 2025. Until then, seasoned players may find there's not much left to do in Monster Hunter World or its DLC expansion, Iceborne, after sinking hundreds upon hundreds of hours into it. Nevertheless, there's always fun to be had in the world of Monster Hunter, especially if players dedicate their time to crafting these extremely fun, extremely overpowered armor sets instead of waiting around doing nothing until Monster Hunter Wilds comes out. Don't worry, we have everything you need to know to build these exciting sets in the tables below!

13 Clutch Claw Heavy Bowgun

Preferred Weapon: Vor Buster

Armor Piece

Decorations

Required Materials

Rimeguard Helm Gamma+

Critical/Vitality Jewel 4 x1, Earplug Jewel+ 4 x1, Maintenance Jewel 1 x1

Velkhana Crown x5, Velkhana Crownhorn x5, Velkhana Ticket x1, Large Elder Dragon Gem x1

Rimeguard Mail Gamma+

Earplug/Maintenance Jewel 4 x1, Maintenance Jewel 1 x1, Expert Jewel 1 x1

Velkhana Fellwing x5, Velkhana Cortex x5, Velkhana Ticket x1, Velkhana Crystal x1

Rimeguard Vambraces Gamma+

Attack Jewel+ 4 x1, Earplug Jewel 3 x1

Velkhana Cortex x5, Velkhana Hardclaw x7, Velkhana Ticket x1, Large Elder Dragon Gem x1

Frostfang Coil Beta+

Attack Jewel+ 4 x1, Earplug Jewel 3 x1, Attack Jewel 1 x1

Silversnow Pelt x3, Frostfang Ticket x1, Bergcrusher Claw x1, Gracium x1

Rimeguard Greaves Gamma+

Attack Jewel+ 4 x1, Shield Jewel 2 x1

Velkhana Cortex x5, Crystal Shard x8, Velkhana Ticket x1, Large Elder Dragon Gem x1

Many newbies to Monster Hunter World , even those familiar with other entries in the series, may be curious to learn about the Clutch Claw . This unique item in World can allow hunters of any weapon type to attach to a monster's side and force them to move in certain directions. A useful tactic for aiding teammates online, a weapon like the Heavy Bowgun can have a lot of fun with Clutch Claw.

This set seeks to take advantage of the Clutch Claw, with level 7 Attack Boost, Earplugs to resist monster roars, and Agitator to attract the attention of monsters. It's also a simple set made mostly out of Velkhana armor, with the exception being the Frostfang Barioth armor for the waist piece. For HBG users not used to moving around, this Clutch Claw set offers a lot of unexpected fun.

12 Fire And Ice Dual Blades

Preferred Weapon: Fire And Ice

Armor Piece

Decorations

Required Materials

Kushala Glare Beta+

Critical Jewel 2 x1, Expert Jewel 1 x1

Daora Cortex x4, Daora Shard x3, Daora Hardclaw x1, Large Wyvern Gem x1

Kushala Cista Beta+

Handicraft Jewel+ 4 x1, Critical Jewel 2 x1

Daora Cortex x4, Daora Fellwing x3, Daora Lash x2, Pure Dragon Blood x6

Kaiser Vambraces Alpha+

Critical Jewel 2 x1

Teostra Cortex x3, Teostra Hardhorn x1, Hellfire Shard x3, Fulgur Anjanath Mantle x1

Kaiser Coil Alpha+

Handicraft Jewel 3 x1

Teostra Cortex x3, Teostra Fellwing x1, Hellfire Shard x3, Pure Dragon Blood x3

Kaiser Greaves Beta+

Sharp Jewel 2 x1

Teostra Cortex x3, Teostra Fellwing x2, Fire Dragon Hardclaw x2, Anjanath Mantle x1

Fire and Ice are very unique weapons in the Monster Hunter franchise, featuring both elemental damage with Ice and status effects with Blast. The combo of these two can make Dual Blade users a serious threat in terms of elemental damage, and this set featuring Master Rank Kushala Daora and Teostra armor sets only brings out the best of these weapons.

For starters, level 5 Handicraft takes the mediocre Sharpness of Fire and Ice up to white level, and both armor sets give enough Ice and Blast Attack buffs to significantly boost the Dual Blades. Adding in skills like Critical Eye via Decorations is also a great way to make sure these Dual Blades are getting the most out of every hit.

11 Immortal Lance

Preferred Weapon: Empress Lance "Styx"

Armor Piece

Decorations

Required Materials

Empress Crown Beta+

Sharp Jewel 2 x1, Shield Jewel 2 x1

Lunastra Cortex x3, Lunastra Mane+ x3, Lunastra Hardhorn x2, Large Elder Dragon Gem x1

Vaal Hazak Mail Beta

Tenderizer Jewel 2 x2

Vaal Hazak Carapace x3, Vaal Hazak Fang+ x3, Vaal Hazak Tail x2, Odogaron Plate x1

Vaal Hazak Braces Beta

Medicine Jewel+ 4 x1, Recovery Jewel 1 x1, Vitality Jewel 1 x1

Vaal Hazak Fang+ x3, Vaal Hazak Membrane x2, Vaal Hazak Gem x1, Deceased Scale x6

Vaal Hazak Coil Beta

Blast Jewel+ 4 x1, Blast Jewel 1 x1

Vaal Hazak Carapace x5, Vaal Hazak Wing x4, Vaal Hazak Membrane x2, Elder Dragon Blood x3

Empress Greaves Beta+

Flawless Jewel 2 x1, Tenderizer Jewel 2 x1

Lunastra Cortex x3, Lunastra Shard x2, Lunastra Fellwing x2, Tempered Cragbone x3

Lance users are already used to being pretty much immortal with their immense Guard skills, but this mixed set of Lunastra and Vaal Hazak armor ups the ante. In place of typical Lance skills, this set prioritizes health-related skills like Health Boost and Recovery Up through its Decorations, but with enough points towards Guard and Evade Extender to support multiple Lance playstyles.

This build pairs especially well with Lunastra weapons, like the Empress Lance "Styx," which boasts a lot of Blast, 10% affinity, and white Sharpness. It even has two level-3 Decoration slots, which can be utilized to boost Guard or Evasion skills depending on which one players have more fun with, but either way, they'll be nearly impossible for Master Rank monsters to kill.

10 Raging Brachydios Great Sword

Preferred Weapon: Lightbreak Blade

Armor Piece

Decorations

Required Materials

Brachydium Helm Beta+

Attack Jewel+ 2 x1, Charger/Vitality Jewel 4 x1, Expert Jewel 1 x1

Brach Obliterator x2, Brach Warhead x1, Indestructible Ebonshell x2, Large Elder Dragon Gem x1

Damascus Mail Beta+

Expert Jewel+ 4 x1, Critical Jewel 2 x1, Expert Jewel 1 x1

Legiana Fellwing x1, Pure Dragon Blood x2, Meldspar Ore x3, Purecrystal x1

Brachydium Braces Beta+

Critical/Vitality Jewel 4 x2

Brach Obliterator x2, Indestructible Ebonshell x2, Flashpoint Slime x3, Shara Ishvalda Gem x1

Ruinous Coil Beta+

Earplugs Jewel+ 4 x1, Expert Jewel 1 x1

Rathalos Mantle x1, Annihilating Greathorn x2, Immortal Shard x1

Brachydium Greaves Beta+

Earplugs Jewel+4 x1, Expert Jewel 1 x2

Brach Warhead x2, Indestructible Ebonshell x2, Flashpoint Slime x3, Immortal Reactor x1

When taking advantage of Blast weapons, it's good to use a weapon that's catered to packing a big punch. That's why this Brachydios Great Sword set is among one of the most thrilling in Monster Hunter World . It prioritizes the right skills for Great Sword, from Attack Up to Earplugs, with additional points in Focus and Health Boost.

What especially makes this a fun set for online play with the best hunters is the Agitator Skill, which draws a monster's attention away from other hunters and onto the player with the skill. This can allow Great Sword users to spend most of their time landing explosive hits on monsters while teammates go nuts with long-ranged weapons or even Insect Glaive or Hunting Horn buffs.

9 Slugger Hammer

Preferred Weapon: Safi's Shattercrusher

Armor Piece

Decorations

Required Materials

Frostfang Helm Beta+

Challenger Jewel+ 4 x1, Tenderizer Jewel 2 x1, Maintenance Jewel 1 x1

Silversnow Pelt x2, Bergcrusher Claw x1, Cryo Sac x3, Frostfang Ticket x1

Brachydium Mail Beta+

Critical/Vitality Jewel 4 x1, Tenderizer Jewel 2 x1, Attack Jewel 1 x1

Brach Warhead x1, Brachydios Pallium x1, Indestructible Ebonshell x2, Flashpoint Slime x3

Frostfang Braces Alpha+

Tenderizer Jewel 2 x1, Critical Jewel 2 x1

Silversnow Pelt x2, Silverwhite Frostfang x1, Bergcrusher Claw x1, Frostfang Ticket x1

Brachydium Faulds Beta+

Critical/Vitality Jewel 4 x1, Expert Jewel 1 x1

Brach Obliterator x1, Brachydios Lash x1, Indestructible Ebonshell x2, Bazelgeuse Mantle x1

Frostfang Greaves Alpha+

Expert Jewel 1 x2

Silversnow Pelt x2, Silverwhite Frostfang x2, Large Wyvern Gem x1, Frostfang Ticket x1

The Hammer is a weapon that's especially made for stunning monsters, which is achieved by hitting them repeatedly in the head until they see stars. It can be a useful technique for online parties, making the monster incapacitated to allow for a free-for-all. That's why this set makes the most of the Hammer's specialties, with Skills like Weakness Exploit, Flinch Free, and Attack Up.

This build also equips Hammer users with Slugger, a Skill which makes stunning monsters easier to achieve. The only downside is that players will have to overcome both the Raging Brachydios and Frostfang Barioth in order to acquire the materials to craft. Still, it'll be worth it if only to allow players the opportunity to make hunts all the more brutal.

8 Fatalis Armor Switch Axe

Preferred Weapon: True Fatalis End

Armor Piece

Decorations

Required Materials

Dragonhead Beta+

Attack Jewel+ 4 x2, Tenderizer/Protection Jewel 4 x1

Fatalis Cortex x3, Fatalis Hardhorn x1, Fatalis Evil Eye x1, Stygian Zinogre Skymerald x1

Dragonhide Beta+

Tenderizer/Maintenance Jewel 4 x1, Brace/Evasion Jewel 4 x1, Critical/Protection Jewel 4 x1

Fatalis Cortex x3, Fatalis Pectus x3, Fatalis Evil Eye x2, Azure Dragonsphire x1

Escadora Armguards Alpha+

Expert Jewel 1 x1, Protection Jewel 1 x1

Alatreon Mantle x3, Alatreon Pallium x2, Alatreon Diretail x2, Alatreon Direwing x1

Dragonbarbs Beta+

Earplug/Protection Jewel 4 x1, Critical/Maintenance Jewel 4 x2

Fatalis Cortex x3, Fatalis Fellwing x2, Fatalis Pectus x2, Immortal Reactor x1

Dragonfeet Beta+

Expert Jewel+ 4 x2, Handicraft/Maintenance Jewel 4 x1

Fatalis Cortex x3, Fatalis Shard x4, Fatalis Fellwing x2, Large Elder Dragon Gem x1

The Fatalis is no easy battle for hunters of any skill level, but acquiring four of its Beta+ Armor set pieces will allow Switch Axe users to make this incredibly fun build. With the right amount of Armor and Weapon Decorations, as well as Charms, this set can have up to 14 skills. A lot of them are useful for any weapon type, including Attack Boost, Handicraft, Critical Eye, and Divine Blessing.

This Armor build also comes with the unique skill Fatalis Legend, which is acquired from having at least two of the Beta+ or Alpha+ pieces, granting the additional skill Razor Sharp. The Skill Power Prolonger is especially useful for weapons like Switch Axe, as it'll increase the time of buffs acquired when the weapon is in its Sword Form.

7 Awakened Paralysis Hunting Horn

Preferred Weapon: Safi's Bindhorn

Armor Piece

Decorations

Required Materials

Brachydium Helm Beta+

Earplugs Jewel+4 x2, Vitality Jewel 1 x1

Brach Obliterator x2, Brach Warhead x1, Indestructible Ebonshell x2, Large Elder Dragon Gem x1

Grand God's Peer Garbs Beta+

Critical/Vitality Jewel 4 x1, Critical Jewel 2 x1

Rajang Apoplexy x2, Rajang Hardhorn x2, Ghoulish Gold Gorer x1, Large Elder Dragon Gem x1

Brachydium Braces Beta+

Attack Jewel+ 4 x2

Brach Obliterator x2, Indestructible Ebonshell x2, Flashpoint Slime x3, Shara Ishvalda Gem x1

Grand God's Peer Belt Beta+

Earplug/Vitality Jewel 4 x1, Critical Jewel 2 x1, Attack Jewel 1 x1

Rajang Apoplexy x2, Rajang Hardclaw x5, Ghoulish Gold Gorer x1, Velkhana Crystal x1

Brachydium Greaves Beta+

Sonorous Jewel+4 x1, Attack Jewel 1 x2

Brach Warhead x2, Indestructible Ebonshell x2, Flashpoint Slime x3, Immortal Reactor x1

The Raging Brachydios Armor set makes an appearance again with the Hunting Horn set. The Hunting Horn, compared to most other weapons, is usually meant for support, but this build particularly makes it a hunting powerhouse with Skills like Attack Boost, Weakness Exploit, and Maximum Might, though it also keeps the typical Horn Maestro for boosting song buffs.

However, this set also contains pieces from the Furious Rajang, one of the toughest non-Elder Dragons in the franchise. Overall, Hunting Horn users with this set will find themselves dealing massive amounts of damage while also surviving devastating blows, giving them the opportunity to support players online and, most importantly, have fun doing it.

6 Offensive Sword And Shield

Preferred Weapon: Safi's Shatterfang

Armor Piece

Decorations

Required Materials

Kaiser Crown Beta+

Flawless Jewel 2

Teostra Carapace x5, Teostra Horn+ x2, Teostra Tail x2, Firecell Stone x1

Kirin Jacket Alpha+

Flawless Jewel 2 x2

Kirin Silvermane x3, Kirin Thundertail+ x3, Kirin Finehide x1, Brachydios Pallium x1

Kaiser Vambraces Beta+

Tenderizer Jewel 2 x2

Teostra Cortex x3, Teostra Hardhorn x1, Hellfire Shard x3, Fulgur Anjanath Mantle x1

Kaiser Coil Beta+

Challenger Jewel 2, Vitality Jewel 1 x2

Teostra Cortex x3, Teostra Fellwing x1, Hellfire Shard x3, Pure Dragon Blood x3

Garuga Greaves Beta+

Critical Jewel 2 x3

Garuga Cortex x2, Garuga Shard x2, Garuga Silverpelt x3, Fierce Dragonvein Bone x5

The Sword and Shield is notably one of the more basic weapon types in the Monster Hunter franchise, but it's a favorite of many hardcore players due to its versatility. Thankfully, even inexperienced players will get a kick out of this offensive SnS set, consisting of Armor pieces derived from Teostra, Kirin, and Yian Garuga materials.

With the benefit of skills like Blast Attack, players with Blast Sword and Shield weapons will have a lot of fun fighting monsters, which will be easier with additional skills like Critical Eye, Weakness Exploit, and Master's Touch, the latter of which will retain sharpness whenever a player gets a critical hit against a monster. Simply put, SnS users will be happy with this set.

5 Imperial Saber Longer Sword

Preferred Weapon: Imperial Shimmer

Armor Piece

Decorations

Required Materials

Pride Helm Alpha+

Footing Jewel 2

Bazelgeuse Mantle x1, Scorching Silverwing x3, Flickering Silvershell x3, Distilled Blast Fluid x2

Zorah Hide Beta+

Earplugs Jewel 3

Vivid Crimsonbone x3, Heavy Dragonvein Bone x3, Pale Crystal x3, Conqueror's Seal x1

Kaiser Vambraces Alpha+

Footing Jewel 2

Teostra Cortex x3, Teostra Hardhorn x1, Hellfire Shard x3, Fulgur Anjanath Mantle x1

Pride Coil Beta+

Maintenance Jewel+ 4

Bazelgeuse Hardclaw x3, Bazelgeuse Shard x2, Twisted Stouthorn x2, Flickering Silvershell x3

Rath Heart Greaves Beta+

Footing Jewel 2

Pink Rathian Cortex x2, Pink Rathian Shard x2, Rathian Weave x1, Conflagrant Sac x3

The Long Sword can be a tricky weapon to use since it has a long reach and can easily knock fellow players on their feet if they come into contact with it. Therefore, on solo hunts, Long Sword users want an Armor set that will let them continually fight with few interruptions. That's where this mixed set, paired with the Teostra Long Sword, comes in handy.

Among this armor build's skills include Tremor Resistance, Earplugs, Weakness Exploit, and for extra damage with the Imperial Saber, Blast Attack. Additionally, players can equip this set with a Handicraft Charm if they also want increased sharpness. While players will be especially susceptible to Ice attacks, the Blast weapons will even make those fun hunts.

4 Safi'Jiiva Insect Glaive

Preferred Weapon: Safi's Bindspear

Armor Piece

Decorations

Required Materials

Kaiser Crown Beta+

Attack Jewel 4

Teostra Carapace x5, Teostra Horn+ x2, Teostra Tail x2, Firecell Stone x1

Buff Chest Alpha+

Attack Jewel 1, Vitality Jewel x2

Rajang Wildpet x3, Gold Rajang Pelt+ x1, Buff Ticket x1

Kaiser Vambraces Beta+

Attack Jewel 4, Tenderizer Jewel 2

Teostra Cortex x3, Teostra Hardhorn x1, Hellfire Shard x3, Fulgur Anjanath Mantle x1

Kaiser Coil Beta+

Challenger Jewel 4, Critical Jewel 2, Expert Jewel 1

Teostra Cortex x3, Teostra Fellwing x1, Hellfire Shard x3, Pure Dragon Blood x3

Garuga Greaves Beta+

Expert Jewel 4, Critical Jewel 2 x2

Garuga Cortex x2, Garuga Shard x2, Garuga Silverpelt x3, Fierce Dragonvein Bone x5

Insect Glaive users have the benefit of lots to look for in a good Armor set, thanks to the uniqueness and versatility of the weapon. This Armor set, which utilizes the Safi'Jiiva branded Insect Glaive , is among the best, and like quite a few of the best Monster Hunter World builds , it also takes from Teostra armor to make the most of its blast weapon.

This set also has plenty of other Skills that make it quite overpowered, from an Attack Boost that can rise to Level 7 if worn with an appropriate Attack Charm. There's also Critical Eye, Agitator, and Latent Power, which are all great skills for any Insect Glaive set. Unlike the Long Sword, however, Glaive users don't have to worry about disrupting online comrades.

3 Diablos Charge Blade

Preferred Weapon: Diablos Tyrannis II

Armor Piece

Decorations

Required Materials

Ruinous Helm Alpha+

Ironwall Jewel 1

Nergigante Cortex x3, Eternal Regrowth Plate x4, Annihilating Greathorn x3, Glavenus Mantle x1

Damascus Mail Beta+

Artillery Jewel 1 x3

Legiana Fellwing x1, Pure Dragon Blood x2, Meldspar Ore x3, Purecrystal x1

Drachen Vambraces Alpha+

Sharp Jewel 2, Magazine Jewel 2

Behemoth Mane x3, Behemoth Bone x3, Behemoth Tail x1, Behemoth Great Horn x1

Empress Coil Gamma+

Lunastra Horn x2, Lunastra Scale+ x4, Lunastra Mane x2, Lunastra Ticket x1

Kushala Cocoon Gamma+

Elementless Jewel 2, Charger Jewel 2

Daora Carapace x5, Daora Dragon Scale+ x4, Daora Webbing x3, Daora Ticket x1

Of all the monsters in Monster Hunter World to derive a weapon from, Diablos is probably one of the hardest to conquer. For hunters who have already done the hard work of obtaining the Diablos Tyrannis II , the fully upgraded Charge Blade, they'll get a lot out of this intimidating Armor set, comprised of many Elder Dragon Armor set pieces.

Adding in a Handicraft charm, which will increase standard Sharpness for the quite dull Diablos Tyrannis, Charge Blade users will have a lot of fun with us. Other skills like Artillery, Focus, Guard, and Capacity Boost all specifically benefit Charge Blade users, so when combined with this immensely powerful weapon, Diablos will no longer feel like a threat.

2 Blast Bow

Preferred Weapon: Safi's Shatterbow

Armor Piece

Decorations

Required Materials

Safi Crested Crown Beta+

Physique Jewel 4, Vitality Jewel 1 x2

Safi'jiiva Fellwing x5, Safi'jiiva Shard x4, Safi'jiiva Hardhorn x3, Zionium Crystal x1

Safi Crested Chest Beta+

Vitality Jewel 4, Furor Jewel 2

Safi'jiiva Cortex x6, Safi'jiiva Hardclaw x5, Pulsing Dragonshell x4, Deviljho Crook x1

Safi Crested Vambraces Beta+

Spread Jewel 3, Tenderizer Jewel 2 x2

Safi'jiiva Cortex x6, Safi'jiiva Shard x7, Pulsing Dragonshell x5, Zinogre Skymerald x1

Safi Crested Belt Beta+

Spread Jewel 3, Expert Jewel 1

Safi'jiiva Cortex x6, Safi'jiiva Shard x7, Safi'jiiva Hardhorn x5, Velkhana Crystal x1

Safi Crested Boots Beta+

Forceshot Jewel 3, Mighty Bow Jewel 2, Fortitude Jewel 1

Safi'jiiva Cortex x6, Safi'jiiva Fellwing x4, Safi'jiiva Lash x3, Large Elder Dragon Gem x1

What sets this overpowered set apart from many others is that it's entirely composed of weapons and armor from the Safi'Jiiva, an Elder Dragon exclusive to Monster Hunter World: Iceborne. This means that players will have to fight that monster a lot to gather all the material for five Armor pieces, as well as its fully-upgraded Bow, the Safi's Shatterbow.

Once this laborious task is complete, Bow users will have an incredibly useful set on their hands. After including charms, decorations, and mantles, this set has many reliable skills for Bow users, such as Bow Charge Plus, Evade Window, Resentment, and Spread/Power Shots. It'll make even a ranged weapon user feel in the action.

1 Immortal Any Weapon

Preferred Weapon: Any Safi'Jiiva Weapon

Armor Piece

Decorations

Required Materials

Dragonhead Beta+

Hard Dragon Res Jewel 4, Hard Thunder Res Jewel 4, Hard Ice Res Jewel 4

Fatalis Cortex x3, Fatalis Hardhorn x1, Fatalis Evil Eye x1, Stygian Zinogre Skymerald x1

Dragonhide Beta+

Protection Jewel 1 x3

Fatalis Cortex x3, Fatalis Pectus x3, Fatalis Evil Eye x2, Azure Dragonsphire x1

Fellshroud Braces Beta+

Protection Jewel 1, Defense Jewel 1, Recovery Jewel 1

Vaal Hazak Cortex x3, Vaal Hazak Fellwing x2, Shadowpierce Fang x2, Large Elder Dragon Bone x5

Dragonbarbs Beta+

Protection Jewel 1, Medicine Jewel 1, Recovery Jewel+ 4

Fatalis Cortex x3, Fatalis Fellwing x2, Fatalis Pectus x2, Immortal Reactor x1

Dragonfeet Beta+

Potential Jewel+ 4, Hard Defense Jewel 4

Fatalis Cortex x3, Fatalis Shard x4, Fatalis Fellwing x2, Large Elder Dragon Gem x1

The ultimate goal of any hardcore Monster Hunter player is to eventually find an Armor build that makes them virtually indestructible during hunts. In Monster Hunter World: Iceborne , that'll be this set, composed mostly of Fatalis Armor pieces. However, it boasts positive resistance to all elements except for Fire and over 1304 defense, including Decorations.

Other skills will also do good to keep hunters from dying, such as Divine Blessing, Defense Boost, Recovery Up, and Recovery Speed. With this set equipped and basic knowledge of literally any weapon type in the game, it'd actually be a much more impressive feat to still cart three times in a single hunt, given just how overpowered it is.

item.title: The Return of One Final Fantasy 14 Collab Should Open the Floodgates for Another Crossover
item.description:
Final Fantasy 14 fans have something exciting to look forward to as Square Enix has announced the return of the highly-popular Fall Guys collaboration event, just ahead of the release of Patch 7.1. Starting on October 23, players will be able to participate in unique Fall Guys -inspired attractions at the Manderville Gold Saucer, with a chance to earn exclusive rewards like glamours, housing items, and mounts. The collaboration, originally introduced during the 2023 Las Vegas FanFest, will run for a few weeks, giving players a limited window to collect Manderville Gold Saucer Fame (MGF) points.

This collaboration could be the spark that ignites other collaborations with popular video games. Such collaborations would be a boon for Final Fantasy 14 as it continues its live services. Its great popularity will only continue with more and similar collaborations.

Building on Success: Why More Final Fantasy 14 Crossovers Could Follow

The Fall Guys collaboration's success demonstrates that there is potential for more crossover events with indie games in Final Fantasy 14 . Popular games like Among Us could provide the next opportunity for unique collaborations. The massive appeal of these games, especially among younger audiences, presents a significant chance for Final Fantasy 14 to attract new players who are already familiar with these titles. An Among Us crossover could easily incorporate mini-games and glamours inspired by the colorful crewmates and imposters, fitting perfectly within the whimsical atmosphere of the Manderville Gold Saucer.

Additionally, Final Fantasy 14 has shown its ability to stay relevant in pop culture. For example, the unexpected popularity of the baby hippo Moo Deng proved that Square Enix can successfully tap into viral trends and capitalize on them. This adaptability, combined with a potential Among Us collaboration, could further expand the game's audience and connect parents who have been playing Final Fantasy 14 for over a decade with their children, fostering intergenerational gaming experiences.

Why Collaborations Help Keep Final Fantasy 14 Fresh

With over eleven years under its belt, Final Fantasy 14 is continually finding ways to stay fresh and engaging for both long-term players and newcomers. Crossovers like the Fall Guys event introduce new mechanics, aesthetics, and mini-games that diversify the gameplay experience. This not only keeps veteran players entertained but also makes the game more approachable to new players who might be familiar with other titles.

Attracting Different Types of Final Fantasy 14 Players with Indie Game Crossover Events

Incorporating popular indie games like Fall Guys and Among Us could help Final Fantasy 14 attract a new demographic of players, who may be more engaged with other genres like multiplayer and battle royale titles than traditional MMORPGs. With games like Fortnite and Among Us still dominating the gaming space, collaborations that bring elements from these titles into Final Fantasy 14 could be the key to reaching a new audience of gamers. These crossover events also present a unique opportunity for families, with parents who are long-time Final Fantasy 14 players able to share these experiences with their children.

Final Fantasy 14 has long been praised for its ability to evolve with its community, and crossover events like this are a testament to that adaptability. As the Fall Guys collaboration returns, it's clear that the game's developers are keenly aware of the importance of keeping the game relevant to broader gaming culture. If Square Enix continues to explore partnerships with popular indie games, it could pave the way for Final Fantasy 14 to maintain its momentum and grow its player base well into the future.
